quotes.quote: One man practicing sportsmanship is far better than a hundred teaching it.
I think sportsmanship is knowing that it is a game, that we are only as a good as our opponents, and whether you win or lose, to always give 100 percent.
I can accept failure. Everyone fails at something. But I can't accept not trying.
Sportsmanship for me is when a guy walks off the court and you really can't tell whether he won or lost, when he carries himself with pride either way.
If you spend a lot of time on sportsmanship, you're going to spend a lot of time losing.
I would prefer even to lose with honor than to win by cheating.
The greatest test of courage on earth is to bear defeat without losing heart.
True sportsmanship is excellence in motion!
It's good sportsmanship to not pick up lost golf balls while they are still rolling.
Sometimes I think sportsmanship is a little bit forgotten in place of the individual attention.
You are never really playing an opponent. You are playing yourself, your own highest standards, and when you reach your limits, that is real joy.
Champions keep playing until they get it right.
It does not matter how many times you get knocked down, but how many times you get up.
To play is in the mind. To win is in the heart.
Victory is in the quality of the competition, not just the final score.
Be more concerned with your character than with your reputation.Your character is what you really are while your reputation is merely what others think you are.
I never thought about losing, but now that it's happened, the only thing is to do it right.
Every game, you have so many people watching you. You can show good sportsmanship by helping other players up, and not talking back to coaches and referees.
Sportsmanship is not just about being nice. It is much more important than that. It's about realizing that you could not compete without an opponent and that she has the same goals as you.
When you win, say nothing. When you lose, say less.
Never let a win get to your head, or a loss to your heart.
Win as if you were used to it, lose as if you enjoyed it for a change.
Sportsmanship, next to the Church, is the greatest teacher of morals.
Sportsmanship is making sure you have respect for the guy you're playing across from.
There is value in any experience that exercises those ethical restraints collectively called sportsmanship.
Winning isn't everything, but wanting to win is.
Don't praise your own good shots. Leave that function to your partner who, if a good sport, will not be slow in performing it.
No matter if you win or lose, the most important thing in life is to enjoy what you have.
What winning is to me is not giving up, is no matter what's thrown at me, I can take it. And I can keep going.
Losing is no disgrace if you've given your best.
